Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for IEEE Cyber Security Development Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support student travel to the 2016 IEEE Cyber Security Development Conference to be held in Boston in November 2016. The Cyber Security Development Conference (SecDev) provides a venue for presenting ideas, research and experience about the development of secure systems. SecDev is distinguished by its focus on how to "build security in". Its goal is to encourage and disseminate new ideas for secure system development among both academia and industry.

SecDev encourages students to consider "big" ideas that will lead to a stimulating, thoughtful, and perhaps (gently) provocative discussion. The support from NSF will be used to sponsor travel expenses for students to attend the conference. The training and development of students in this way will help to widen the talent pool of professionals and researchers focused on addressing challenges of developing critical secure systems and services. The proposed effort particularly encourages students from under-represented populations and institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this grant was to broaden the participation of students from diverse backgrounds in disciplines of engineering and computer science in conducting research in the area of cyber security and secure systems. The inaugural IEEE Cyber Security Development (SecDev) conference in Boston, Massachusetts on Nov 3-4, 2016 provided an opportunity for students to learn about the state-of-the-art methodologies and technology for cyber security. 

This award provided financial support to ten undergraduate and graduate students from seven higher education institutions in the United States to attend the SecDev conference.  Students were provided partial support for travel, registration and lodging expenses. The SecDev 2016 conference included three keynote addresses from cybersecurity experts in government and academia. Eight tutorials and twenty-six technical talks were presented. Seventeen full conference papers are archived and available on the web at http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/mostRecentIssue.jsp?punumber=7838558 .

Travel awards were advertised at fifty Universities and Colleges including Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). Twenty-five grant applications were received and reviewed by a committee of six technical experts from academia and industry. Ten students including five females and five students from HBCUs were awarded grants to participate in the conference. Two of the awardees presented their research at the conference.  The students attended tutorials and presentations provided by leading researchers, policy makers and practitioners in the cyber community.  The conference created  a forum for direct and substantive interactions between students and cyber security professionals. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/23/2017
Modified by: Kavitha Chandra
